metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of ground truth measurement synchronizing with MODIS in the Linze grassland foci experimental area on Jun. 2, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of ground truth measurement synchronizing with MODIS was obtained in the Linze grassland foci experimental area on Jun. 2, 2008. Measurements were carried out twice at intervals of 125m in four quadrates (2km×2km), which were H01-H08, H09-H16, H17-H24 and H25-H32 respectively. Simultaneous ground data were mainly the canopy temperature, the half-height temperature, the land surface radiative temperature and the soil temperature (0-5cm) by the probe thermometer.
    For soil moisture, the soil temperature, soil moisture, the loss tangent, soil conductivity, and the real part and the imaginary part of soil complex permittivity were acquired by the POGO soil sensor, and soil gravimetric moisture, volumetric moisture, and soil bulk density after drying by the cutting ring inNo.1 quadrats (H01-H08), No.2 (H09-H16) and No.3 (H17-H24); and in No.4 quadrat 4 (H25-H32), soil moisture, soil conductivity, the soil temperature, the real part of soil complex permittivity were acquired by WET, soil gravimetric moisture, volumetric moisture, and soil bulk density after drying by the cutting ring.
    Complementary measurements were carried out on Jun. 3, 2008. The soil temperature, soil moisture, the loss tangent, soil conductivity, the real part and the imaginary part of soil complex permittivity were acquired by the POGO soil sensor, and soil gravimetric moisture, volumetric moisture, and soil bulk density after drying by the cutting ring in H41-H48, H49-H56 and H57-H64; and in H33-H40, soil moisture, soil conductivity, the soil temperature, and the real part of soil complex permittivity were acquired by WET, soil gravimetric moisture, volumetric moisture, and soil bulk density after drying by the cutting ring.
    Data were archived in Excel format. See WATER: Dataset of setting of the sampling plots and stripes in the Linze station foci experimental area for more information.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features measured during ground-based synchronized observations for MODIS data in grassland areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: canopy temperature, surface temperature, shallow soil moisture, soil temperature, soil moisture, dielectric properties, electrical conductivity, soil bulk density, moisture content

Quantification.Question: How many measurement points are there at 125m intervals for surface temperature and soil moisture collection in the specified area?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using MODIS ground synchronous observation in data collection for surface and canopy temperature measurements?
Definition.Answer: MODIS ground synchronous observation involves conducting ground measurements of surface and canopy temperatures at the same time as satellite overpasses. This method is significant because it provides a point of reference for validating and refining satellite-based data, ensuring accuracy in the retrieval of surface temperature and evapotranspiration estimates. In this context, measurements include canopy temperature, surface thermal radiation temperature, and soil temperature, which are essential for comparisons with satellite data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in synchronizing ground-based temperature and soil moisture measurements with satellite data in remote sensing experiments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in synchronizing ground-based temperature and soil moisture measurements with satellite data can be attributed to factors such as the spatial and temporal resolution differences between ground measurements and satellite observations. Additionally, the time-intensive nature of soil moisture measurement, which required an additional day to complete, indicates logistical challenges in conducting comprehensive synchronous measurements. Variability in soil moisture content and temperature at different depths and locations, along with the need for precise calibration of instruments like infrared thermometers and soil moisture sensors, also contribute to these challenges.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of using synchronous ground-based measurements of canopy and surface temperatures on the accuracy of satellite-derived land surface temperature estimates?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using synchronous ground-based measurements of canopy and surface temperatures can significantly enhance the accuracy of satellite-derived land surface temperature estimates. By providing precise ground truth data, these measurements help in calibrating and validating remote sensing models, allowing for more accurate inversion and verification of satellite data. This can lead to improved accuracy in the estimation of surface temperature and evapotranspiration from airborne and satellite remote sensing data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of conducting ground-synchronized observations of canopy and surface temperature alongside soil moisture measurements in remote sensing experiments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of conducting ground-synchronized observations of canopy and surface temperature alongside soil moisture measurements is to provide a fundamental dataset for the inversion and validation of surface temperature and evapotranspiration data from airborne and satellite remote sensing platforms.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to conduct synchronized MODIS ground observations for canopy and surface temperature measurements in a grassland area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To conduct synchronized MODIS ground observations for canopy and surface temperature measurements, it is necessary to follow a procedural approach that includes selecting a 2km×2km area with designated sample plots (H01-H32). Measurements should be taken along four east-west transects (H01-H08, H09-H16, H17-H24, H25-H32) at 125m intervals. These measurements involve using handheld infrared thermometers to record canopy, mid-height, and surface thermal radiation temperatures, as well as using needle thermometers to measure soil temperature at a depth of 0-5cm.

Expectation.Question: Why might the collection of soil moisture data in remote sensing experiments experience delays or incomplete measurements, and what strategies could be employed to improve the efficiency of data collection?
Expectation.Answer: Soil moisture data collection can be time-consuming due to the detailed and precise measurements required, such as those involving portable soil sensors and gravimetric methods. In the described field, the soil moisture measurements were not completed on the initial day, necessitating additional measurements on the following day. This delay could be attributed to the complexity and labor-intensive nature of the measurement processes, as well as the spatial distribution of measurement points. Strategies to improve efficiency may include optimizing the spatial sampling design to reduce travel time between points, employing more automated or rapid measurement technologies, or increasing the number of personnel involved in data collection to cover more ground simultaneously.
